meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>fragrance</kanji> <kanji>river</kanji> <kanji>prefecture</kanji> is <vocabulary>Kagawa Prefecture</vocabulary>. Might help to look at the reading first.

To <kanji>fly</kanji> and <kanji>leap</kanji> is <vocabulary>leaping</vocabulary>.

飛躍 is mainly used in a figurative way to highlight remarkable progress in areas like personal growth or technological advancement. It can also describe a logic that jumps suddenly from one point to another without clear connections.

The kanji is <kanji>best regards</kanji> and this can be <vocabulary>best regards</vocabulary> as well. It can also mean <vocabulary>well</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>properly</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>suitably</vocabulary> as well.

A 宜しい (good, okay, all right) <kanji>request</kanji> is when you send your <vocabulary>best regards</vocabulary> to someone. This is a set phrase you say when someone is going to help you out and you're all like "thank you for your help" or "I'm counting on you" or some combination of the two. It's a word you'll see a lot to varying degrees of kanji and length.

繰る is "to spin" (so spinning) and 返す is "to return" (so returning). Put them together and you have something that's spinning and returning to the same spot over and over. Something that does that is repeating itself, making this <vocabulary>to repeat</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to repeat over and over</vocabulary>.
If you know that 避難 is "evacuation" then you know that this is the verb form of that: <vocabulary>to evacuate</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>lean</kanji> and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to lean something</vocabulary>.

Your <kanji>interior</kanji> <kanji>formal name ender</kanji> (person) is the person who's waiting internal, out of the picture (remember, kanji was made forever ago and is pretty sexist). This person is <vocabulary>your wife</vocabulary>.
If 遠慮 is "decline" or "restrain" then the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to decline</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to restrain</vocabulary>.

If something is <kanji>suspend</kanji>ed, it is going <vocabulary>to hang</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to depend on</vocabulary> your actions. We need you to make sure it goes right! Your actions are what we're suspended on!

You have only <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>life</kanji> so do everything with lots of <kanji>eager</kanji>ness (懸命). Do everything <vocabulary>with all one's might</vocabulary>. Go <vocabulary>all out</vocabulary>.
If 扱う is "to handle," the noun version of that is <vocabulary>handling</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>treatment</vocabulary>.

To <kanji>take</kanji> and then <kanji>handle</kanji> means you're taking it and handling it, causing you <vocabulary>to manage</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to handle</vocabulary> something. You got it because you took it.
選択 is "selection" or "choice." If you do the verb version of this, you are going <vocabulary>to select</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to choose</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>title</kanji>, so just think about when someone gives you an awesome title. They are doing this <vocabulary>to praise</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to give praise</vocabulary> to you.

Remember how 内緒 means "secret" or "confidential"? Well, that makes this is a secret <kanji>talk</kanji>, aka a <vocabulary>confidential talk</vocabulary> — like the kind often done by <vocabulary>whispering</vocabulary>.
緩む is "to loosen," but has to do with loosening on its own. This word is when you loosen or relax something, meaning <vocabulary>to loosen</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to relax</vocabulary>.

Remember 贈る, which means "to give a present"? Well, a <kanji>thing</kanji> that you give as a present is <vocabulary>a present</vocabulary>.

Since 贈り物 comes from the verb 贈る, it describes <vocabulary>a gift</vocabulary> not just as an object but as something given with care. You'll often see it in writing or polite speech when someone wants to emphasize the warmth or sincerity behind a gift.
Remember how 沖縄 is "Okinawa"? This is the prefecture, <vocabulary>Okinawa Prefecture</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Presents</kanji> that you give as a <kanji>bribe</kanji> is a form of <vocabulary>bribery</vocabulary>.

You already learned that 逃げる means "to escape," and this verb is when you let something escape, or slip through your fingers. So this means <vocabulary>to miss</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to lose</vocabulary> a good chance, or <vocabulary>to let go</vocabulary> of a good opportunity.

<kanji>Someone</kanji> who has <kanji>escape</kanji>d <kanji>death</kanji> by running away is a <vocabulary>fugitive</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>runaway</vocabulary>. I think there was a movie about that once!
The people who will <kanji>review</kanji> a <kanji>problem</kanji> are those who know more about the problems. They are the <vocabulary>advisor</vocabulary>s.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>review</kanji>. What do you do when you review something? You look back on it. Meaning <vocabulary>to look back on something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to reflect on something</vocabulary>. This can also mean <vocabulary>to be attentive to someone</vocabulary>, for example your family.

This is a transitive verb, meaning it takes a direct object. You look back on the past, you reflect on the consequences of your actions, and you're attentive to your family.
You <kanji>revolve</kanji> to <kanji>review</kanji> the <kanji>record</kanji> of the past. These records are <vocabulary>memoirs</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>reminiscences</vocabulary>.

Something or someone <kanji>resident</kanji> in 日本 (Japan) is <vocabulary>stationed in Japan</vocabulary>.

駐日 is generally used to describe both individuals and institutions stationed in Japan for official duties, such as the 駐日大使 (Ambassador to Japan) or 駐日大使館 (embassy stationed in Japan).
You're a <kanji>resident</kanji> and you <kanji>exist</kanji> in the place you're residing in. That means you have <vocabulary>residence</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>location</kanji> where <kanji>car</kanji>s can be a <kanji>resident</kanji> is a <vocabulary>parking lot</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>resident</kanji> <kanji>detain</kanji>ed in a location who is in the <kanji>army</kanji> is a member of the <vocabulary>stationed troops</vocabulary> at this location. They could also be the <vocabulary>occupying troops</vocabulary> as well.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>gallop</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to gallop</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
An <kanji>electricity</kanji> <kanji>pillar</kanji> is a <vocabulary>telephone pole</vocabulary>. All those wires and telephone wires going to and from those telephone poles.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>chant</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to chant</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>master</kanji> <kanji>chant</kanji>er is the one who is the loudest. He makes sure everyone hears his chants. He's the main <vocabulary>advocate</vocabulary>.

You're <kanji>chant</kanji>ing and you're <kanji>sing</kanji>ing and you're having a gay ol' time. You're <vocabulary>singing</vocabulary> all your <vocabulary>songs</vocabulary> and even the chanting sounds like singing. It's so fun.
An <kanji>alone</kanji> <kanji>chant</kanji> is one you do alone. It's a <vocabulary>solo</vocabulary>!
You're <kanji>sing</kanji>ing and you're <kanji>chant</kanji>ing. It's a gay ol' time. You're <vocabulary>singing</vocabulary> and singing and singing!
People who <kanji>join</kanji> in a <kanji>chant</kanji> <kanji>group</kanji> are people who are in a <vocabulary>chorus</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>choir</vocabulary>.

If you go towards filial piety, you are going to be doing filial piety. Do this for your parents. 孝行 is commonly used in the phrase 親孝行 (also meaning "filial piety") when someone does something kind or thoughtful for their parents, like visiting often, helping them, giving them a gift, or taking them on a trip. By extension, it can also sometimes describe showing devotion toward other loved ones — caring for and respecting them almost as though they were a parent.
<kanji>Not</kanji> <kanji>filial piety</kanji> is when you don't listen to your parents. This is <vocabulary>disobedience to parents</vocabulary>.

A person with <kanji>genius</kanji> and <kanji>talent</kanji> is a <vocabulary>genius</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>person of exceptional talent</vocabulary>. So smart!

俊才 is an advanced word usually only seen in writing. It tends to refer more to the kind of genius or talent that can be developed through effort. In that sense it differs from 天才, which is for the kind of genius that comes from heaven — either you have it or you don't.
<kanji>Concurrently</kanji> with my current <kanji>business</kanji> I have a <vocabulary>side business</vocabulary>. It's really a <vocabulary>second job</vocabulary>, actually.

If you <kanji>concurrently</kanji> <kanji>use</kanji> one thing for multiple purposes, you're using something with a <vocabulary>combined use</vocabulary>. Something that is <vocabulary>serving two purposes</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>concurrently</kanji>, but since you can't "to concurrently", we're going to have to come up with another word to use: "<vocabulary>to combine</vocabulary>" or "<vocabulary>to double as</vocabulary>." Since this kanji has to do with something having a dual purpose, we can say that something can combine as being another thing, or double as being another thing, which is where these words come from.
<kanji>Wash</kanji> your clothes with a <kanji>dose</kanji> of <vocabulary>detergent</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>medicine</kanji> <kanji>dose</kanji> is <vocabulary>medicine</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>drugs</vocabulary> you're taking.

A <kanji>medicine</kanji> <kanji>dose</kanji> <kanji>expert</kanji> is someone who knows exactly how much dose of each medicine you should be getting. The person who specializes in this is a <vocabulary>pharmacist</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>prevent</kanji> <kanji>rot</kanji> <kanji>dose</kanji> is a dose of something you put on your cut or wound that prevents it from rotting (or you put it on something else to prevent it from rotting). This is an <vocabulary>antiseptic</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>preservative</vocabulary>.
If you take a <kanji>dose</kanji> of something, you are taking a <vocabulary>dose</vocabulary> of <vocabulary>medicine</vocabulary>. Take your cough syrup, child!
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>blow</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to blow</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The <kanji>inside</kanji> <kanji>ditch</kanji> is the inner ditch, or, if you make it awesome enough, the <vocabulary>inner moat</vocabulary>. If they get through the outer moat, we have the inner one, at least!
The <kanji>outside</kanji> <kanji>ditch</kanji> is the ditch around our town that's on the outside (not the inside ditch, which is the inner moat). This is the <vocabulary>outer moat</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>ditch</kanji> <kanji>river</kanji> is a <vocabulary>canal</vocabulary>.
You <kanji>patrol</kanji> and <kanji>revolve</kanji> around the block to make your <vocabulary>patrol</vocabulary>. You're <vocabulary>going around</vocabulary> patrolling.
A <kanji>patrol</kanji> of <kanji>thanks</kanji> is a patrol you make to something you're thanking. Sounds religious. Sounds like a <vocabulary>pilgrimage</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>patrol</kanji>, but what do you do when you patrol? You go around, which is <vocabulary>to go around</vocabulary>.

Those who <kanji>patrol</kanji> and <kanji>inspect</kanji> are <vocabulary>police officer</vocabulary>s or <vocabulary>patrol officer</vocabulary>s.

巡査 specifically refers to the lowest-ranking officers in the police force in Japan, whose duty is patrolling or doing things around 交番 (police boxes), or responding to emergency calls.
I say my <kanji>commandment</kanji> in order <vocabulary>to warn</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to caution</vocabulary> the people not to do bad things.

A <kanji>commandment</kanji> is <kanji>announce</kanji>d to you, but you should take it more as an <vocabulary>admonition</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>warning</vocabulary>. You're an adult after all, so people don't get to command you around.

My <kanji>instruction</kanji> is my <kanji>commandment</kanji>. You must do what I say in my instructions/commandments. This is my <vocabulary>warning</vocabulary>. This is my <vocabulary>admonition</vocabulary>.

My <kanji>warning</kanji> <kanji>commandment</kanji> is there to make sure you take <vocabulary>precaution</vocabulary> and show <vocabulary>vigilance</vocabulary> when it comes to that precaution. It's only a warning commandment, though, which is why it has to do with prevention and precaution.

The <kanji>emit</kanji>ted <kanji>energy</kanji> of some machine is <vocabulary>exhaust</vocabulary>. This can also refer to <vocabulary>ventilation</vocabulary>. Think of it as air (energy) being emitted so new, fresh air can take its place!

When you <kanji>expel</kanji> <kanji>other</kanji>s, you're practicing <vocabulary>exclusion</vocabulary>.

排他 is usually used in the phrase 排他的 (exclusive), which is a formal word that describes a tendency to exclude or reject those who are not part of a particular group.
<kanji>Emit</kanji>ted <kanji>water</kanji> is what we call <vocabulary>drainage</vocabulary>.
Things that are <kanji>emit</kanji>ted and then <kanji>exit</kanji> are, well, <vocabulary>emission</vocabulary>s.

If you <kanji>expel</kanji> or <kanji>exclude</kanji> something or someone, that's called <vocabulary>exclusion</vocabulary>. Alternatively, you could also call this <vocabulary>removal</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>elimination</vocabulary>.

排除 is a relatively formal word that refers to the act of removing or eliminating something undesirable or unwanted.

A <kanji>portable</kanji> <kanji>belt</kanji> is something so portable you can put it on your belt. It is <vocabulary>portable</vocabulary>. Note, this is also a very common term for a <vocabulary>cell phone</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mobile phone</vocabulary>. You'll learn more about that in the coming levels.

Somehow the kanji <kanji>portable</kanji> turns into the verb <vocabulary>to engage in</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to participate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to take part in</vocabulary>. I suppose if you are portable, you're able to engage in all kinds of things, since you can move all over the place, participating everywhere you can (rather than being not portable and being stuck in one place).

If you have an <kanji>alert</kanji> <kanji>feeling</kanji>, you are <vocabulary>sensitive to</vocabulary> things going on around you. That means you have a lot of <vocabulary>sensitivity</vocabulary>!
You've <kanji>surpass</kanji>ed what is normal <kanji>alert</kanji>ness. You are too alert. You notice everything. This is <vocabulary>oversensitivity</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>machine</kanji> <kanji>alert</kanji> is an alert that is timed by a machine, not by a human. It's pretty <vocabulary>quick</vocabulary>. It's also <vocabulary>quick-witted</vocabulary>. Machines can move and think so much faster than us, after all.

機敏 is often used to describe the way someone responds <vocabulary>prompt</vocabulary>ly to various situations, and implies being highly responsive and adaptive.

Someone on <kanji>sharp</kanji> <kanji>alert</kanji> has a <vocabulary>sharpness</vocabulary> about them. They are <vocabulary>quick witted</vocabulary> and have a strong <vocabulary>keenness</vocabulary> to them.

This word is formal and literary.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>sharp</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>sharp</vocabulary>.
Something that is <kanji>sharp</kanji> will <kanji>benefit</kanji> from its <vocabulary>sharpness</vocabulary>, since that's all it has, really.

Something that is <kanji>new</kanji> and <kanji>sharp</kanji> (presumably because it's so new) is on the <vocabulary>cutting edge</vocabulary>. It's <vocabulary>up-and-coming</vocabulary>, the next big thing!

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>spread</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to spread out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to lay out</vocabulary>.

This word generally refers to laying something flat, like a carpet or a picnic blanket. This use also extends to laying railroad tracks or asphalt for street paving. Metaphorically, it describes laying down something foundational, like establishing rules or specific organizational systems.
<kanji>Spread</kanji> the <kanji>gold</kanji> around. First part, I want you to put in a <vocabulary>security deposit</vocabulary>.

Your <kanji>roof</kanji>s are <kanji>spread</kanji> out around your property. Put these roofs and areas all together and you have your <vocabulary>residence</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>estate</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>sit</kanji>ting <kanji>spread</kanji> is a spread of tatami mats, making up the <vocabulary>tatami room</vocabulary> in a Japanese house.

The kanji means <kanji>Milord</kanji>, and this word used to be a name ender similar to the English title <vocabulary>Lord</vocabulary>, but nowadays it's closer to <vocabulary>Mr.</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>Ms.</vocabulary>. It's rarely used in speaking or even written correspondence these days, but is still used in official documents, and you'll probably see it most on certificates. If in doubt, you're better off choosing the name ender 様 because it's much more widely used, and also more polite than 殿.

<kanji>Milord</kanji> (you say very formally with a <kanji>formal name ender</kanji>). You say it very formally because this person is a lord, or more specifically, a <vocabulary>feudal lord</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Milord</kanji>'s <kanji>hall</kanji> is a nice place. It's where a lord would live. A <vocabulary>palace</vocabulary>. By extension, this can also mean a <vocabulary>sanctuary</vocabulary>, and even a <vocabulary>hall of fame</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>sacrifice</kanji> <kanji>hit</kanji> is one you do in baseball, when you hit the ball in the air, and then the person on third tags up and scores. In baseball, this can either be a <vocabulary>sacrifice bunt</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>sacrifice fly</vocabulary>.
If you <kanji>seize</kanji> and <kanji>acquire</kanji> you're making an <vocabulary>acquisition</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>possession</vocabulary> of something.
To <kanji>catch</kanji> and <kanji>seize</kanji> is <vocabulary>capture</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>seizure</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>seize</kanji>d <kanji>thing</kanji> is something you've seized from your victory. It's your <vocabulary>spoils</vocabulary>. It's your <vocabulary>trophy</vocabulary>!

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>luxuriant</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be luxuriant</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to grow thickly</vocabulary>.
Something that is <kanji>overgrown</kanji> and <kanji>luxuriant</kanji> must have quite the <vocabulary>luxuriant growth</vocabulary>. Lots and lots of growth.

Something that is <kanji>frequent</kanji>ly <kanji>overgrown</kanji> is something that is super <vocabulary>frequent</vocabulary>. It never stops attacking, never stops coming, and is honestly getting <vocabulary>incessant</vocabulary> in how often it overgrows. Those darn [put plant name here].
Something that is <kanji>overgrown</kanji> and will <kanji>multiply</kanji> is obviously <vocabulary>breeding</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>multiplying</vocabulary> a ton.
If you're <kanji>overgrown</kanji> with <kanji>prosper</kanji>ity you are probably really <vocabulary>prospering</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>frequent</kanji>ness of something, measured in <kanji>occurrence</kanji>s is measured in <vocabulary>frequency</vocabulary>.
Something that <kanji>frequent</kanji>ly <kanji>departure</kanji>s has much frequency and is a <vocabulary>frequent occurrence</vocabulary>. Oh, that? Yeah, it departures with much frequency.
Something that goes towards being <kanji>frequent</kanji> is something that is <vocabulary>frequently</vocabulary> happening.
<kanji>Life</kanji>, when it <kanji>multipl</kanji>ies (multiply), is doing <vocabulary>reproduction</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>multiply</kanji> and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to multiply</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to increase</vocabulary>.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>dilute</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>dilute</vocabulary>. And something that's been diluted is now <vocabulary>thin</vocabulary>.
Something is <kanji>dilute</kanji>d to the point of <kanji>weak</kanji>ness. It has much <vocabulary>weakness</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>feebleness</vocabulary>.
If you <kanji>dilute</kanji> <kanji>feeling</kanji> from someone, they have no feelings. They become <vocabulary>cold hearted</vocabulary>.

If you <kanji>collide</kanji> and <kanji>attack</kanji> what you're colliding into, you're going to not only cause a large <vocabulary>shock</vocabulary> but also <vocabulary>crash</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>impact</vocabulary> into them. Blamo!
When things <kanji>collide</kanji> and <kanji>thrust</kanji> into each other, you have a <vocabulary>collision</vocabulary>, or at least a strong <vocabulary>impact</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>famous</kanji> <kanji>honor</kanji> is still an <vocabulary>honor</vocabulary>, but it is also a <vocabulary>prestige</vocabulary> to have, since you are famously honorable. So prestigious!
You have a <kanji>prosper</kanji>ity of <kanji>honor</kanji>, therefore you have <vocabulary>honor</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>praise</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to praise</vocabulary>.
I <kanji>praise</kanji> you for your <kanji>beauty</kanji>. I'm so into your beauty, I hand you a <vocabulary>reward</vocabulary>... a <vocabulary>prize</vocabulary>, basically.
I <kanji>praise</kanji> you for what you did, so here's your <kanji>prize</kanji> to go along with my praise, a <vocabulary>medal</vocabulary>!

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>transparent</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be transparent</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be see-through</vocabulary>.

透ける is usually for things that are partially transparent or see-through because they're thin or sheer, like stockings and lace curtains. Sometimes people even joke that your true thoughts are 透けてる (showing through).
Something that is <kanji>transparent</kanji> and <kanji>bright</kanji> so that you can see through it is <vocabulary>transparent</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>neighbor</kanji> <kanji>house</kanji> is a <vocabulary>neighboring house</vocabulary>. That house is right next to ours!
All the <kanji>near</kanji> <kanji>neighbor</kanji>s are the people who live around you and near you. They're a part of the <vocabulary>neighborhood</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>neighbor</kanji> <kanji>country</kanji> is a <vocabulary>neighboring country</vocabulary>. For us, our 隣国 in America are those sneaky Canadians... always waiting to strike, I can tell...
A <kanji>neighbor</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>neighbor</vocabulary>.
If everything you <kanji>do</kanji> is <kanji>elegant</kanji> you have <vocabulary>artistry</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>good taste</vocabulary>. So much <vocabulary>elegance</vocabulary>!

It's so <kanji>elegant</kanji> and so <kanji>comfort</kanji>ing. This is <vocabulary>Japanese court music</vocabulary>, and it's what fancy court people listened to in Japan back in the day. You can also call it <vocabulary>gagaku</vocabulary> if you'd like.
Something that is <kanji>superior</kanji> and <kanji>elegant</kanji> has much <vocabulary>elegance</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>grace</vocabulary>.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>void</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>empty</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>vacant</vocabulary>. Just think of what has to happen to make a void in the first place.
Remember when you learned 房? Well it can be used as a counter for clusters of fruit. Like a <vocabulary>section</vocabulary> of an orange or a <vocabulary>bunch</vocabulary> of grapes! Yum!

You're so <kanji>glad</kanji>, you get <kanji>glad</kanji> again. No matter what you're doing, it's undoubtedly in a <vocabulary>state of enjoyment</vocabulary>.

嬉々 itself refers to a <vocabulary>joyful state</vocabulary> where someone happily does something. It's generally used as the adverb 嬉々として, which means “happily” or “gladly.” While less common, it can also serve as an adjective when combined with たる.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>glad</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>glad</vocabulary>!

In your <kanji>knee</kanji> there is a <kanji>small</kanji> <kanji>priest</kanji> named <vocabulary>Kneecap</vocabulary>.

This is a really common, cute way of talking about your kneecap. It's usually used by kids and adults alike, and it's more common in spoken Japanese than 膝頭. Kind of like how we use "kneecap" instead of naming the "patella" bone all the time.
A <kanji>supernatural</kanji> <kanji>spirit</kanji> flutters up to you. It's a <vocabulary>fairy</vocabulary>!
What's <kanji>supernatural</kanji> and <kanji>suspicious</kanji>? A <vocabulary>monster</vocabulary>, or, if you know the Japanese term, a <vocabulary>yokai</vocabulary>.

You can guess this is an adjective by looking at the い it ends with. One of the meanings of the kanji, <kanji>enchanting</kanji>, is already an adjective. That's the meaning of this word, too: <vocabulary>enchanting</vocabulary>. What is enchanting? It's basically <vocabulary>charming</vocabulary> in a <vocabulary>mysterious</vocabulary> way.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>dilute</kanji>, and this is an intransitive verb, as you can guess from the まる ending. So this verb means <vocabulary>to be diluted</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be diminished</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to become weak</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Grab your <kanji>noodle</kanji> <kanji>pole</kanji> and let's make some noodles. What's a noodle pole? It's a <vocabulary>rolling pin</vocabulary>!

You use your rolling pin to flatten out the noodle dough before you slice it into noodles. That's why a rolling pin is so important to make noodles.
You already know that 中華 means Chinese, and <kanji>麺</kanji> means noodles. Put them together and what have you got? That's right, <vocabulary>Chinese noodles</vocabulary>! Yum!

You know that 麺 means "noodles", and つゆ is another word for "soup" or "broth". Put the two together and you have the delicious <vocabulary>mentsuyu </vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>noodle soup base</vocabulary>. It's usually made of dashi, soy sauce, mirin and sugar​. Yum!

If someone <kanji>abduct</kanji>s what do they <kanji>do</kanji>? That's <vocabulary>abduction</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>kidnapping</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>taking captive</vocabulary>. This word comes up fairly frequently in Japanese newspapers, and is often used to refer to kidnappings carried out by North Korea in the seventies and eighties.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Get Out Into The World
To Be Out In The World

meaning_mnemonic: Here we have <kanji>world</kanji> with the particle に, following by the verb 出る (to go out). Put that together and this means <vocabulary>to go out into the world</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be published</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be released to the public</vocabulary> in some way or another. Once it's out there in the world, there's even a chance for it <vocabulary>to become renowned</vocabulary>.

meanings.meaning: To Go Out Into The World
To Be Released To The Public
